The Cabinet noted that, although the White Paper on constitutionalUgislat development in Northern Ireland had been better received in then Province than might have been expected, a number of the Government sown supporters appeared to be mounting a campaign against the proposed legislation. The Cabinet further noted that the official Opposition were at present in favour of the debate on the White Paper in the week beginning 26 April taking place on a take note motion. A reasonable time would have to be allowed between the debate and the Second Reading of the Bill, but there was no reason why the Bill should not be published and introduced in the course of the following week,The Cabinet -1. Agreed that the proposed legislation on Northern Ireland should be introduced in the House of Commons in the course of the following week.9l*Ms. THE FOREIGN AND COMMONWEALTH SECRETARY said that in theL Agency context of the Falkland Islands situation it might be necessary to intro-6gi8lation duce emergency legislation to deal with such matters as therequisitioning of ships and aircraft and the expulsion of Argentinian nationals from the United Kingdom. He was in discussion with the Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Trade about the need for and timing of emergency legislation, and the drafting of a Bill on a contingency basis had almost been completed.THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR TRADE said that a particular problem arose in relation to the Trading with the Enemy Act. If Argentina declared war on the United Kingdom, the draconian provisions of the Act would automatically come into effect. It would be preferable for the Act to be brought into force by Order in Council, and any emergency legislation should contain a provision to this effect.The Cabinet -2.
